awd_titl_txt: Categorical Methods for Classical, Equivariant, and Motivic Homotopy Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
Classical homotopy theory studies the shape of space in a very coarse, flexible and approximate sense. Rigid geometric notions such as distance and curvature play no role; instead, at heart is the notion that one space can be continuously deformed into another. Over the last 50 years the methods and scope of homotopy theory have been significantly generalized and expanded as mathematicians have realized that there are many situations where analogous notions of "continuous deformation" can be found or defined. Indeed we now know that there are many different homotopy theories to be found in mathematics and that they arise in a wide range of mathematical disciplines. In this project, the PI aims to apply the methods of tensor triangular geometry to four distinct but thematically-related problems in classical, equivariant, and motivic homotopy theory. The problems the proposal aims to solve are significant questions in their respective subjects and yet the techniques proposed to tackle these problems are not mainstream methods from the heart of algebraic topology. The general approach used is extremely interdisciplinary, using the platform of tensor triangulated categories to pass ideas and techniques between diverse mathematical subjects. Indeed, the proposed work will strengthen the interconnectedness of modern mathematics by transferring ideas and techniques between algebraic topology, algebraic geometry and representation theory. Moreover, the proposed research program will extend and develop the techniques of tensor triangular geometry, a broad research program which aims to develop algebro-geometric methods for reasoning about a wide variety of homotopy theories arising throughout mathematics.

In the first project, the PI aims to continue recent momentum in understanding the spectrum of equivariant stable homotopy theory with the goal of completing the computation of the spectrum for all finite groups and for pursuing generalizations to the case of compact Lie groups. The second project proposes a method to prove a twenty-year-old conjecture of Palmieri concerning the classification of modules over the Steenrod algebra, an important object of classical algebraic topology that has been intensely studied for over sixty years. In the third project, the PI shall use a strategy to compute the spectrum of an important piece of the motivic stable homotopy category. Finally, the PI will also use a categorical approach to the Picard group of motivic stable homotopy categories, which has the potential to clarify what little is known about these groups. A common theme in the proposed methods is the generalization and application of methods which have been successful in modular representation theory by passing through the unifying world of tensor triangulated categories. A second common theme is the use of an analogue of the etale topology in tensor triangular geometry.

por.por_cntn:
Tensor triangulated categories arise in a diverse range of mathematical disciplines from algebraic geometry and algebraic topology to representation theory and beyond. Tensor triangular geometry is a theory currently being developed which studies tensor triangulated categories from a geometric perspective. It can be regarded as a broadening of algebraic geometry in which tensor triangulated categories form the basic geometric objects of study. The goal is to generalize methods and ideas from algebraic geometry to the much more general setting of tensor triangular geometry and then apply these generalized methods to tensor triangulated categories arising in areas of mathematics far removed from algebraic geometry. It is a highly interdisciplinary subject.

The basic mechanism for passing from tensor triangulated categories to geometry is the Balmer spectrum. Computing the Balmer spectrum of a tensor triangulated cateogry is a fundamental yet difficult problem which lies at the heart of this geometric perspective.

The major research outcomes of the project include.

1. Theoretical advances in tensor triangular geometry: The project has deepened our theoretical understanding by providing tensor triangular geometry with a notion of finite etale morphism, which is an algebro-geometric analogue of finite covering map (Sanders, 2022), and by deepening our understanding of surjectivity (Barthel-Castellana-Heard-Sanders, arXiv, 2023).

2. A theory of stratification in tensor triangular geometry: The project has also developed a general theory of stratification in tensor triangular geometry (Barthel-Heard-Sanders, Cambridge Journal of Mathematics, 2023), which provides powerful new tools for understanding big tensor triangulated categories throughout mathematics. This theory is quite general and covers all known classifications theorems for big tensor triangulated categories in the literature. Moreover, the project develops the method of descent for establishing stratification (Barthel-Castellana-Heard-Naumann-Pol-Sanders, 2023), deepens the relationship between stratification and the spectrum (Barthel-Heard-Sanders, The Quarterly Journal of Mathematics, 2023), and develops an extensive theory of costratification (Barthel-Castellana-Heard-Sanders, arxiv, 2023).

3. Applications to equivariant homotopy theory: The project has considerably deepened our understanding of the tensor triangular geometry of equivariant stable homotopy theory. In particular, it provides a complete computation of the Balmer spectrum of the category of derived Mackey functors, which can be regarded as a sort of "linearization" of the equivariant stable homotopy category (Patchkoria-Sanders-Wimmer, 2022). The result obtained is very complete and quite elegant. We find that this space captures precisely the top and bottom layers (i.e. the height infinity and height zero parts) of the spectrum of the equivariant stable homotopy category. We also provide an understanding of the chromatic truncation of the equivariant stable homotopy category (Barthel-Heard-Sanders, Cambridge Journal of Mathematics, 2023) and establish that both the linearizations and truncations are stratified. These results deepen our understanding of the relationship between equivariant and chromatic homotopy theory.
